title: Are Hungarians Mongols? Despite Slavic and Romanian people have higher ratio of mongoloid markers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hungarians are genetically more European than most slavic speaking people (who contain more Asian mongoloid Y and mt.DNA haplogroup markers), but all Northern Germanic nations (incl. Northern Germany too) have higher ratio of Mongoloid haplogroup markers . See the ratio of Central Asian haplogroup „Q” and the other mongoloid haplogroup marker „N” (aka. N1C1) markers in the largest genetic database and CHART of European nations: European Y-DNA haplogroups frequencies by country And see the high ratio of middle-eastern haplogroup markers (various „J”) and african negroid origin (E1b1) marker in all balkan populations (inc. Romania). De facto, these nations populations genetically are less European than Hungarians. The Eurasian plains had a lot of horse nomad cultures throughout history, from a very diverse genetic and linguistic backgrounds: Indo-Europeans (Iranians, for example), Semites, Turkic and Mongolian peoples, etc. Most of the groups were loose confederations of extended families, or clans, allying themselves with stronger clans, usually through a series of intermarriages. One of these groups was what later would become the core of Hungarian nation, had Urali origins, but was influenced very early on by Turkic during their migrations, then after they arrived in the Carpathian basin (which already had a mix of people with different ethnicity, the remainder of the Huns for instance) they invited several Turkic tribes to settle, then the Mongols and the Tatars arrived, then the Ottoman Turks and another group of Tatars, and so on. While we do have quite a lot of Turkish in our language (20–30%), genetically we are about 98% Slavic/Germanic - with a touch of Iranian, just for good measure, but not much linguistic or genetic relation to Mongols or other Altai groups.

No. Hungarians are a people whose national origins come from north of the Caspian Sea on the steppes of central Russia. Today there are many other ethnicities like German and Croatian blended into the Hungarian ethnic fabric. Mongols are not part of that.
